body.p:
Dept. Pro. Marshals Office
Smithland Ky
June 28th 1864
Brig Gen Burbridge
Louisville Ky
Dear Sir

The 11th day of May 1864. Oscar Turner Lytle. of McCracken County was arrested at Paducah by Col S. G. Hicks, Comd Post at Paducah, Said Turner Lytle was accused of stealing mules from Blunt Hodges a noted copperhead the mules were all found, & the man has been turned over to the Civil Authorities & his Examining ^trial^ pushed through he could not get his witnesses as they had run off from the draft.

Mr Lytle is a Union man has I am informed rendered important service to the Government as a Federal Scout is a respectable man. & has been Drafted by Capt. R. H. Hall, of Paducah still the man is immured in a vile loathsome jail and Hodges his accuser Now says he thinks he Turner Lytle is an innocent man

Yesterday his Lady came up & Brought 2 men up who are true Union men, one lives in the same yard with Mr Lytle, who on
Being duly Sworn testified that on May 11.th 1863 O. Lytle was at his home during the entire night & was at home Every night frim the 10th to the 13th of May thus clearly proving on Alabi his bond is fixed at $500, which could be quickly given were he not drafted to go into the army for 3 years or more. John & S. W. Gentry have sworn to what I state above

Now General we most Respectfully request you to devise some plan or grant us an order for the Body of Oscar Lytle, so we can turn him over to Capt Hall where he has been drafted. He is quite willing to go & fight for his country -- if released, the Court does not sit until August, & from Judge Fowler down,including 9/10 of the Jury are all intense Copperheads or Southern right sympathizers, & he TLytle will have at the best only a mock trial.
^(Except James Cade Clk of Court)^

We are General
Very Respectfully
Your Obedt Servt
John L. Seaton
Dept. Pro. Marsh at Livingston Co
John W. Bush Capt Co G
48th Ky vols, Comdg Post, Smithland Ky

McCracken Cir C
vs
Oscar Lytle
Pardoned
230thJuly/64
sent to
John L. Seaton
Dep Pro Mars
Livingston Co
